Our story begins as our heroes return from their latest foray into the depths of a nearby dungeon. Weighed down with loot and carrying their sorely wounded companions, the adventurers trudge happily towards town. Suddenly, disaster strikes. The skies go from clear blue to pitch black, wind whips around the travellers, and rain drenches them to the skin. It's an unpleasant day. Groaning, the companions quickly set up tarps and attempt to light a fire, but have no success.
And we're live! Is there a point? Is there any reason to create such a beast? No! Outstanding.

I saw a couple of neat things on the roads in the last couple days. The first was a store that I can only assume did car "tricking out." The name of the store was "Carsmetics." Heh. I like that one. The second was a road sign that used to say something that has now slipped my mind, but now, thanks to some sort of (probably illegal) modifications, says "try." I just thought that was cool.

It's a blog; it's rarely used; is there a purpose? Not likely. I guess my real difficulty is that I have no idea who or what my audience will (could) be. When I send an email I know who's going to get it. Write a paper, draw a picture, build something: the recipient is always pre-defined. But this...well, thanks to the Internet I don't have a clue who'd ever see it. That's both exhilerating and frightening at one and the same time. Hmm. It's freeing as well.

There's no excuse for it, but I'm sitting home alone and doing nothing but watching TV and surfing the web. How bad is that? I know I should just get up and go out, but I just don't want to bother with it. I'm sure I'll come up with something, but the wait until then is annoying.

That's about the only reason I can come up with for my feelings of general malaise. The reason I'm wondering if it has something to do with rhythyms is that this tends to happen every once in a while, and to go away just as quickly. There's nothing that sparks it, but neither is there anything that ends it. Now it's just a matter of time before it goes away. The worst part is that there's so much good in my life right now, that there really is no reason for any kind of depression. Ah well, time heals all.

What are the right words to Robert Frost's poem, Fire and Ice? Specifically, I'm looking for the right word in the following lines. "I think I know enough of hate, To [blank] that for destruction, ice" I've seen it both as "know," and "say." The Internet, formerly infallible, comes up with both versions at about a 50-50 ratio. So, which is right?

You all know the rule: "I before E, except after C, unless sounding like A, as in neighbor and weigh, unless it's weird." Well, I've found a weird one, but in the other direction. "Deficient" breaks the rule, sort of, so what I figured was to tack on a phrase to the end. "...it's weird, or deficient." Yeah, it sounds odd, but it's grammatically correct, and that's about the best I can do.

I've recently realized that the term "aether" really should be involved in some sort of accepted scientific doctrine. It's just too darn good a word to be relegated to the backwaters of the late 19th and early 20th centuries' random scientifically experimental attempts. I mean, just look at it...aether. How cool is that. Speak it aloud, let the syllables roll off your tongue. I'm not even sure how many syllables it has. Doesn't that just rock? I guess I should now toss out some conventional scientific theory that could be enhanced by the addition of our "word of the day," but I'm not going to. I'm just going to let all of you nonexistent readers out there come up with your own theories as to how best we could serve "aether." Sweet.
